channel.title: Communism
channel.description:
Communism is ofter related to country's such as China and the former Soviet Union. But let's define Communism: "Communism is the theory of a classless social system in which all property and means of production are owned in common; socialist theory deriving from the works of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels." It also means that everyone is equal. If everyone is equal, you don't have a government, because the people in a government wouldn't be equal to the rest. So you can ask yourself: was the Soviet Union really a communistic union?
The Soviet Union had 2 main leaders. First Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov, also known as Vladimir Lenin. He was the one that led the October-Revolution. After his death in 1924, he was replaced by Josef Stalin. Stalin was the one that everyone feared. Stalin led a terror regime. Anyone that was in the way of his ideas was either killed or sent to a Gulag.
But let's connect the dots. Communism means that everyone is equal. Everyone lives in harmony with eachother. The population is represented in soviets, or counsils. So everyone has an equal amount of power. Stalin, and Lenin aswell, were dictators. They had all the power. According to Lenin, it was a neccesary step towards full communism. First, the state aqcuires all property, and then it's equally divided between the population and the state stops existing. Lenin died before he could complete his plans. Stalin would never do the last step, he was satisfied with his power.
To summarize: Communism is different from what most people think. The USSR wasn't (and China isn't) a communist country.

item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:34, topic:243921”]Who has more power, you or your teacher?
You are not equal.[/quote]

If the parents, or in high school the students, hear that a teacher isn’t doing his job right, they tell the representative of their counsil.

Let’s say that Mr. Jones is a teacher. He tells his students that they can do whatever they want, as long as they don’t tell anyone. Mr. Jones get’s paid, but he doesn’t teach his students anything. As you saw in one of my previous posts, there is a middle or city counsil. That counsil deals with things like education per school. If needed, some people are asked to come and tell about the teacher. If the counsil thinks that it’s running out of hand, they plan a meeting. They invite the teacher, students that he teaches, parents and if needed other teachers. In this case it’s obvious that the teacher gets fired, and he’ll probably wont be a teacher anymore.

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:34, topic:243921”]Who has the more power, the theacher or the headmaster?
The teacher can’t fire the headmaster, but the headmaster can fire the teacher.
They are not equal.[/quote]

The teachers decide what is best for their school, they don’t need a headmaster. The city counsil tells them what the parents expect from the school, and the teachers plan how to do that. That’s plain logic, because not everyone knows how to run a school. Lets say that in school A they teach Economics, English, Maths and Spanish. Teachers that teach Spanish, don’t know how much about Maths. So it’s obvious that Spanish teachers compose the booklist for Spanish, and the Maths teachers compose the booklist for Maths. So the lower level of running a school is dealt with.

But to run a school you also have to decide what blackboards you need, how many computers you need etc. This is done by all teachers. They come together and explain how many, and why, they need an x amount of computers for their course. Then they make a plan on how many they actually buy.

Edit: I had to eat, so I only replied to the last post. Here is my reply to the others:

PeterMan:

So, the counsil proposes a suggestion, and people “vote”? Wouldn’t that make them democratic? Because it would not be equal if the counsils make all the decisions.

The counsil is controlled by the people, and the people are the counsil. There are higher counsils so that you don’t have a meeting of 2 million people, but smaller numbers.

goatee:

I personally believe that in theory, communism is fantastic and the answer to all our problems. The only problem is that it’s very difficult to convert an already established country to a completely different way of life. For communism to be successful it must start from scratch, a perfect place to test communism would be something like… a moon colony where everyone is on equal terms and can grow up with communism instead of adapting to it.

That’s the reason behind the revolution started by Lenin. His idea was that in order to reach true Communism, the state had to acquire everything. When that is completed, the ‘state’ stops existing and the counsils (the population) takes over.

RXVL:

Communism is a very, very, intelligent idea, but sadly it will never work because of the greedy bastards in the world that just want power.

I agree with you that greed is the main factor that stands between capitalism and communism. I have no solution for that, other then waiting for a great depression, that hurts every single person (rich or poor).
